thesis.description: There is a reason to believe, on experimental and on theatrical grounds, that Y-rays, X-rays, light rays, heat radiation, Bertzian waves and longer radio waves, all have a common velocity in space and differ essentially only as to their frequency of oscillation. Newton succeeded in splitting up "white" light into a series of colours ordered in a certain way, called the visible spectrum. This visible spectrum has limits of wave-length 8000 Angstreem units for the red to 4000 Angstroem for the violet. These wavelengths are measured by taking advantage of the phenomenon of interference, which suggests a disturbance of wave form as in a stretched string. [...]
thesis.creator: McRae, Duncan Ross.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The absorption of infra-red rays by water, ice andother substances.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The inconsistencies which have been observed and reported by Snell (1), among others, when the determination of the Canadian Lead Number of maple products is carried out by different investigators, have long been connected with the basicity of the lead acetate reagent used in the determination. However, there is wide divergence not only between the results of different collaborators, but also in different series of experiments by the same investigator. In addition, comparable results have been obtained by different investigators using different basic lead acetate solutions. [...]
thesis.creator: Mitchell, Claude Ritson.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The influence of the composition of basic lead acetateon the Canadian lead number of maple products.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is a well known fact that culture media, when sterilized by autoclaving, undergo certain changes which affect their original constitution. Attention is here drawn to the abundance of precipitated substances, the changes in hydrogen ion concentration, the hydrolysis of carbohydrates, and the formation of caramel in heat-sterilized culture solutions. The catalytic effect of heat in making these rapid alterations, and possibly others also which have so far evaded observation, proves to be a disadvantage in physiological studies which call for an exact knowledge of the chemical constitution of the media employed. [...]
thesis.creator: Montserin, Blazini G.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies on culture media.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Le but de cette étude est de déterminer 1'attitude d'Anatole France envers l'Eglise, et particulièrement ses idées sur les prêtres catholiques. A cette fin, J'ai divisé ce traité en deux parties principales. La première partie traite des sources possibles, qui, selon mon Jugement, ont pu contribuer à influencer l'auteur dans la formation de ces idées religieuses, et ainsi dans ses opinions des prêtres de la religion catholique. En d'autres tenues, nous allons d'abord étudier ces choses qui le conduirent à rejeter le culte de ses ancêtres. [...]
thesis.creator: Mclnnis, Sarah.
thesis.subject: French.
thesis.title: Les caracteres ecclesiastiques dans I'oeuvre d'Anatole France.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The literature in defence or condemnation of slavery is touched on in Section Two. It seemed unnecessary to consider separately this question of "politiaal freedom", since the publications in Nova Scotia had no direct bearing on the struggle for emancipation, fought out many years later. Besides the references given in Section Two, there are theofficial letters and records relating to the deportation of twelve hundred negroes from Nova Scotia to Sierra Leone in 1792. The story of this event, and Zachary Macaulay's connection with it, is related by Sir Adams Archibald; and a full account of the institution of slavery as it affected British North America is given by T. Watson Smith D. D. of Halifax. [...]
thesis.creator: Nelson, Eda M.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The literature of the Maritime Provinces of Canada and its bearing on the struggle for educational and political freedom.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The history of a literature must go back in its earliest beginnings to the spoken expression of -the traditions--mythical or real--of the race or heroes of the race. These traditions have become known as folk-lore or folk-song, depending upon whether they are told or sung. They are passed on orally from generetion to generation. Gradually by means ofscribes these stories of events and heroes are written down and form the background of a nation's literature much of which is mythical, especially when it attempts to account for the beginnings of the race. It is not strange therefore that in the early lore of practically all nations we find natural heroes elevated to gods and tales of gods and heroes who possess god-like qualities continuously overlap. [...]
thesis.creator: O'Brien, Margaret T.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The influence of Irish folk-songs and folk-lore on English literature.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The trend of the latter part of the eighteenth and the early part of the nineteenth century was a noticeable "return to nature". It was perhaps both the cause and the effect of the French Revolution, which had grave effects in England as well as in France. "It is no idle Hibernianism to say that toward the end of the eighteenth century, the most important event in English history happened in France." (1) This is amply illustrated by the contemporary and subsequent English literature. It is not the purpose of this treatise to discussthe various causes and effects of the French Revolution. I am simply stating a well known fact, in recognizing the revolt against the prevailing artificiality in English Literature of that period as one of the indirect effects of the French Revolution. [...]
thesis.creator: Mullaly, Jessie Rosalie.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Religious experience of Francis Thompson.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: George Moore, either by his own management or by the intervention of fate, has been an outstanding figure of every important literary movement within the last fifty years. Perhaps fate has had more to do with it than Mr. Moore would like to admit, if Matthew Arnold's statement be true that, "for the creation of a master of literature two powers must concur, the power of the man and the power of the moment, and the man is not enough without the moment." Certainly Moore has had the good fortune to be a spectator of several of the mostradical and interesting literary experiments which have engaged the attention of the intellectual aristocracy for half a century. [...]
thesis.creator: Murray, Mae F.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The influence of the French naturalists on the work of George Moore.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The history of philosophy belng a progressive synthesis of interpenetrating doctrines, all divisions into periods are of a large arbitrary character. If recent philosphers are taken to be all those from the English Idealistic school onwards, this arbitrariness can be supported by many obvious considerations which sill appear throughout the following pages. The new systems which were presented during that time, are best regarded as attempts to modify neo-Kantianism by viewing mind in a more concrete and specific manner. The positions credited by these men to mind vary from its being unconditionally constitutive of all reality to its merely resulting from a set of neutral particulars organized in a peculiar way.[...]
thesis.creator: Henderson, Thomas Greenshields.
thesis.subject: Philosophy.
thesis.title: The concept of mind in recent thought.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Birds differ fram mammals in having only one gland of a sebaceous nature. This is the glandula uropygialis, commonly known as the oil gland or preen gland. It is present in most birds and is always situated at the base of the tail. It secretes an oily substance whioh by means of the beak is smeared all over the feathers. It 1s generally thought that 1n this way birds oil their feathers in order to prevent wetting. Does this account for the existenoe of the gla.nd? Can birds oontinue to live without the gland? Has it any other function than merely to oil the plumage? In other words, is it neoessary for the maintenance of life or for the preservation of the feathers? [...]
thesis.creator: Hou, Hsiang-Ch’uan.
thesis.subject: Uropygial gland.
Birds -- Anatomy.
Physiology.
thesis.title: Studies on the glandula uropygialis of birds.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The entire mining world has watched the growth ot the Rouyn mining distriot in the last few years; from a practically unknown and unexplored territory into an area which gives promise of becoming one of the world's important sources of copper. To those who are interested in this area, either financially or otherwise, any small contribution to thepetrography or ore relations of any part ot the region is likely to prove valuable. It is the purpose of this Thesis to make some such contribution, and it is the hope of the writer, that, at least, a few of the results obtained will lead to a better and more detailed knowledge of a part of this interesting area. [...]
thesis.creator: Holbrooke, George L.
thesis.subject: Geological Sciences.
thesis.title: Petrographic study of the Aldermac mine.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The acourate determination of specific heats is a matter of some importance in Physics and Chemistry. Divers methods have been used by investigators, each suited to its own particular purpose. In the case of gases, comp1ications arise owing to the existence of two speoifio heats, one at constant volume and one at constant pressure. It oocurred to Dr. Keys that certain experimental methods, which he was using for another purpose, might be adapted to the accurate determination of specific heats of gases at constant volume by the explosion method. Certain facts must be ascertained before this adaption is possible, however, and these points have engaged the attention of the writer. As the experimental methods of Dr. Keys' form the basis of the work and as they will be adopted when making actual observations of specific heats, they will be discussed in detail below. [...]
thesis.creator: Henderson, John T.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: A study of the time-pressure curves of explosions in gaseous mixtures at constant volume by a Piezo-electric method.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Even in the earliest stages of the economic growth of any country, the use of "credit" may be found to have existed, as the means by which, the exchange of goods and commodities was facilitated. Wherever it is found that people began to live together even in the smallest of communities, it is apparent that they have been prompted to exchange their goods with their neighbours. With this exchange of goods there soon grew up the need for a medium of exchange, but it might even be maintained that the use of credit has preceded the the adoption of any exchange medium. Credit has been defined as "the power to obtain goods or service, by giving a promise to pay money(or goods), on demand or at a verified date inthe future." (1) [...]
thesis.creator: Little, John W.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: Credit and credit facilities in Canada : with special reference to current commercial practice and merchandising methods.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Process cheese is a special form of prepared cheese, the term "process" being applied by Dr. J.A. Ruddick, Dairy and Cold storage Commissioner of the Department of Agriculture. By various processes of heating and emulsifying, well matured cheddar cheese is made into a palatable, homogeneous product, which lends itself easily to moulding-into various shapes,sizes and weights. This bacterial study of process cheese was undertaken to find out the numbers and kinds of bacteria found in the cheese when sold to the consumer; to ascertainthe effect of the pasteurizing temperature on the germ content; and to study those organisms which find access to the cheese during the course of manl1facture and after thepasteurizing process is completed. [...]
thesis.creator: Irwin, Marion Lenora.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
thesis.title: The bacteriology of process cheese.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: If the importance of any work of any particular period can be judged by the number of MSS that preserve it, Piers Plowman may be considered one of the outstanding Literary Productions of the 14th century, for while 57 MSS have preserved Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, 45 MSS have preserved Piers Plowman. Who can say that the numerous MSS of the Canterbury Tales are not due to their popularity? None. The same no doubt can be said of Piers Plowman. "Next to the Canterbury Tales," says Jusserand, "the poem usually called Piers Plcwman is the greatest literary work produced by England during the Middle Ages. It is thoroughly English, not a tinge of foreign influence can be found anywhere in it. [...]
thesis.creator: Hudson, James C.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The social ideals of William Langland.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of this investigation is to study the anatomical arrangement of the vascular systems of the uterus and placenta during different age periods of pregnancy, and to show the relation of one to the other. The structural alterations in those circulatory systems following upon senile changes, and the relation of such changes to the blood content of those organs, will also be dealt with. The greater part of our present day knowledge of the placenta has been derived from investigation of the growth, disposition and change in its epithelium as be fits a glandular organ. [...]
thesis.creator: Kearns, Peter J.
thesis.subject: Pathology.
thesis.title: Anatomy and pathology of placental circulation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The most superficial survey ot the literature on mythology and folk-lore shows that there ls no monotony in the multitude of opinions. In all times and ln all plaoes men have tried to discover why the lore of their country, both classic and popular, is interwoven with so many references to ancient gods and goddesses; to strange events, deeds. and beings; or to natural happenings influenced by unnatural agencies. Stories that treat of divinities once worshipped by Greek, Roman, Norse, or German forefathers are classic myths. Tales told bycontemporary savages are living myths. Fragments, or surviva1s of old beliefs or customs, found among uneducated people in civilized countries, are called folk-lore. [...]
thesis.creator: Maclean, Mary Winifred.
thesis.subject: Mythology -- Psychological aspects.
Folklore -- Psychological aspects.
Psychology.
thesis.title: Psychological aspects of myth and folk-lore.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The problem of relaxation oscillations in gases is so intimately connected with the more general problem of electrioal discharges through gases that I shall in these introductory remarks give some of the general aspects of the theory of gas discharges in its present form. The phenomenon of electrical conductivity of gases has been noticed by experimenters as far baok as the time of Coulomb. (1) Coulomb observed that a charged conductor suspended by insulating strings would lose its charge much more rapidly than oould be accounted for by leakage over the strings. It was not until late in the nineteenth century that a logical explanation was discovered. [...]
thesis.creator: MacLeod, Malcolm.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: A study of relaxation in oscillations in different gases.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The work described in this thesis was undertaken with the object of aiding in the classification of the spectral lines in the so-called "Seoondary Hydrogen Spectrum". Verylittle work has been done along this line, by the use of observations on the Stark effect and it is entirely probable that the theoretical work in progress at present will lead to predictions which must be tested by such observations. In the present work, sixteen lines showing Stark effects were discovered in the region between 3700 A.U. and 4100 A.U. [...]
thesis.creator: MacDonald, James L.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The Stark-effect in the secondary spectrum of hydrogen.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Association of plants is by no means a new subject for study, though so far reports dealing with association of phytopathogens have been comapartively rare,as a survey of theliterature on the subject indicates. Most attention has evidently been turned to other branches of research. Recently, during an extensive survey of storage rots at Macdonald College and vicinity, it has been observed by the writer that even though the rots were relatively abundant and many vegetables and fruits were attackedtthe number of speciesof pathogenic organisms on a single specimen was very limited. [...]
thesis.creator: Machacek, John E.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies on the association of certain phytopathogens.

thesis.description: The Sea has always awakened a profound emotion in the heart of every true descendant of Celtic or Anglo-Saxon stock. From the far off misty days of these primitive peoples to the present twentieth century, a fervent love of the sea has been, and is destined to remain, a predominating trait in the national character of the British race. To the Celt, the Sea was a beautiful but mysterious and uncontrollable power; he loved it for its majesty and beauty, but he feared it for its great strength, its treachery and its cruelty. [...]
thesis.creator: Murray, Phyllis M.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The English novel of the sea from Smollett to Conrad.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In the following pages an account is given of an investigation of the colloidal properties of meta styrene. Meta styrene is a colloid that swells and disperses yielding lyophilic sols not with water but with organic liquids. From the work on proteins, soaps, tannins and other substances we now have considerable knowledge of the properties of colloidal solutions where water is the dispersion medium, that is to say, hydrophilic colloids. But the class of lyophilic colloids of which meta sytrene is an example, that is organophilic colloids, has, to date, received scant attention. This is due, no doubt, to the fact that they are not as important as the hydrophilic sole which are of particular interest due to their close association with life processes. [...]
thesis.creator: McNally, James G.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Some colloidal and elastic properties of meta styreneand rubber.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Consider any member in a structure. This member, when loaded, carries a certain total stress, which, if divided by the cross-sectional area of the member, will give an average unit stress commonly called the primary stress. This assumes a uniform distribution of stress which rarely, if ever, exists. If it were possible to determine the actual stress existing in any particular fibre, by measuring the strain in that fibre, it would, in general, differ from the Primary Stress. Secondary Stress, as considered in this paper, is defined as the difference between the Primary Stress in any fibre and the stress actually existing in that fibre. [...]
thesis.creator: Morrison, Carson F.
thesis.subject: Civil Engineering.
thesis.title: The effect of the manner of support and ofcertain details of construction on the secondary stresses in a roof truss.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Friction is one of Nature's paradoxes. It is at once a blessing and a curse to huumanity. Without friction, man would be unable to control his movements and continue his existence; yet, because of its presence, he is using up the greater part of his energies. Thus, there are benefits derived from friction which are accepted as a matter of course and with few expressions of appreciation; but at the same time, the action of friction imposes a burden upon man which he carries with a continual struggle and frequent protest. The writer of this essay, following a very human course, will say no more about the virtues of friction, but wi11 consider some of its faults. [...]
thesis.creator: McCurdy, Lyall R.
thesis.subject: Department of Machine Design.
thesis.title: Journal bearing friction characteristics.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Thurso map-area is situated immediately to the east of the districts of Buckingham and of the river Lievre where mining operations have been carried on for many years. Just recently the Singer Mgr. Co. have oonstructed a local line, "The Thurso and Nation Valley Railway", for the transportation of timber from lake Barriere to Thurso. It ls hoped that mineral deposits of economio value will be discovered in the northern portion of this district now open to transportation, and it is largely in view of this that the following geo1ogical investigation was undertaken. [...]
thesis.creator: Pelletier, Rene A.
thesis.subject: Geology & Mineralogy.
thesis.title: Geology of the Thurso area, Quebec and Ontario.
